newsitem.title: ITALY: SanPaolo mulls stable s/holder core - paper.
newsitem.headline: SanPaolo mulls stable s/holder core - paper.

text.p: Italy's largest banking group San Paolo di Torino is likely to seek a stable core of institutional investors and make a public sale offer (OPV) when it takes steps to privatise this year, financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore said.
Il Sole gave no direct source for the report but said talk from the bank indicated it could offer a total stake of around 45 percent to public and institutional investors.
Around 65 percent of San Paolo bank is currently held by the San Paolo Holding company, which in turn is 100 percent controlled by charity foundation Compagnia di San Paolo.
The bank's chairman Gianni Zandano said last year the group was looking to privatise in 1997.
Il Sole said the aim was to reduce the San Paolo holding company stake in the bank to below 20 percent, meaning at least 45 percent would be on offer.

Advisors Morgan Stanley had suggested the group should seek a stable core of shareholders, banks and foreign and Italian industrial-financial institutions, with each taking a three to five percent stake for a total of around 20 percent of San Paolo Spa, the newspaper said.
The rest of the stake could then be offered publically on the stock market, it said.
